page.title: 12Dairying at Leadon Court
page.content: Leadon Court is a dairy farm of 87 hectares. This farmer is changing from Shorthorn and Friesian cows to Holstein because the{Marketing Board pays more for the quality than the amount of milk. 40% of the cattle are Holstein. He breeds his own calves although the 10% cut in quotas has meant a reduction in the size of the herd. These cattle are kept in nearby pastures; outlying pastures are used for silage. {Computer feeding}has now been introduced and ensures that the cattle get a balanced diet all year. Water is supplied from the mains for dairy use but drinking water is pumped from the River Leadon. It is then stored in a reservoir tank. All the milk is sold to the Milk Marketing Board and the farmer's milk is provided by the milkman.
